Qwest's former chief executive, Joseph P. Nacchio, was convicted on 19 of 42 counts of insider trading on Thursday, the latest corporate titan to take a fall for profiting in ways that juries agreed were unacceptable.

During the 15-day trial in Denver, federal prosecutors painted Mr. Nacchio as a greedy executive who hid warnings about Qwest's money troubles from investors, while dumping over $100 million worth of stock in 2001. Defense lawyers argued that Mr. Nacchio stood by the positive financial forecasts he proclaimed in public and was forced to unload his stock because the options were set to expire.
The conviction carries a penalty of up to 10 years in prison and a fine of $1 million for each count. Sentencing has been set for July 27; Mr. Nacchio's lawyers have vowed an appeal.

It's not the only uphill legal battle the once-lauded executive now faces. Mr. Nacchio must also reckon with a hearing on the forfeiture of assets sought by the prosecution and a 2005 civil fraud lawsuit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding revenue reports during his time at Qwest.
